title: Writing Strong Paragraphs
description: Learn the essential elements of a well-written paragraph: topic sentence, supporting details, and concluding sentence.
subject: ink_haven

template_data.instructions: Learn about paragraph structure by answering these questions. A good paragraph has a topic sentence, details, and a conclusion!

choices: The last sentence in a paragraph
The sentence that tells the main idea of the paragraph
A sentence with the word 'topic' in it
expected: The sentence that tells the main idea of the paragraph
questions.hint: It's usually the first sentence and tells what the paragraph is about.
questions.explanation: A topic sentence states the main idea of the paragraph. It tells the reader what to expect.

questions.prompt: Which would be the BEST topic sentence for a paragraph about your favorite season?
choices: Fall is my favorite season for many reasons
expected: Fall is my favorite season for many reasons
questions.hint: A good topic sentence is specific and makes a clear point.
questions.explanation: This topic sentence is specific (names the season) and promises to give reasons, which the paragraph will explain.

choices: Sentences that give examples and information about the main idea
expected: Sentences that give examples and information about the main idea
questions.hint: These sentences 'support' or back up the topic sentence.
questions.explanation: Supporting details are sentences that explain, describe, or give examples about the topic sentence.

questions.prompt:
Read this topic sentence: 'My dog Max is very playful.'

Which would be a good supporting detail?
choices: He loves to chase tennis balls in the backyard
I have a cat named Fluffy
expected: He loves to chase tennis balls in the backyard
questions.hint: Which sentence gives an example of Max being playful?
questions.explanation: Chasing tennis balls is an example that supports the idea that Max is playful.

questions.prompt: What does a concluding sentence do?
choices: Wraps up the paragraph and restates the main idea
expected: Wraps up the paragraph and restates the main idea
questions.hint: It comes at the end and brings closure.
questions.explanation: A concluding sentence wraps up the paragraph and often restates the main idea in a new way.

questions.prompt:
Read this paragraph:

'[Topic] Soccer is an exciting sport. [Detail 1] Players run fast and kick the ball toward the goal. [Detail 2] The crowd cheers when someone scores. [Conclusion] _____'

Which sentence would be the BEST conclusion?
choices: Soccer is played with a ball
That's why so many people love watching soccer
There are 11 players on each team
expected: That's why so many people love watching soccer
questions.hint: A conclusion should connect back to the main idea.
questions.explanation: This conclusion wraps up by connecting back to the main idea that soccer is exciting.

questions.prompt: In what order should the parts of a paragraph go?
choices: Topic sentence, supporting details, concluding sentence
expected: Topic sentence, supporting details, concluding sentence
questions.hint: Think: introduce the idea, explain it, wrap it up.
questions.explanation: Paragraphs flow best when you start with the main idea, add details, then conclude.

questions.prompt: How many supporting details should a good paragraph have?
questions.hint: You need enough details to explain your main idea well.
questions.explanation: A strong paragraph typically has 2-3 supporting details that fully explain the topic sentence.

questions.prompt:
Read these sentences:

1. Pizza has many delicious toppings like pepperoni and mushrooms.
2. Pizza is the best food.
3. Everyone should try pizza!
4. The melted cheese is so tasty.

Which sentence should be the topic sentence?
questions.hint: Which sentence states the main idea that the others support?
questions.explanation: Sentence 2 is the topic sentence. Sentences 1 and 4 are supporting details, and sentence 3 is the conclusion.

questions.prompt: True or False: Every sentence in a paragraph should relate to the topic sentence.
questions.hint: Paragraphs should stay focused on one main idea.
questions.explanation: True! Every sentence should connect to the main idea. Sentences that don't fit should be removed or saved for another paragraph.
